candidates.title: libs: add flatipc implementation
candidates.body:
flatipc is a new method for doing IPC. This is a zero-copy approach where structs are given `repr(C)` implementations that are well-defined and work across process boundaries.

If the same struct or enum is used in two processes that has the same layout, then data can be freely passed between the two processes without incurring a serialization or deserialization penalty, provided the following hold:

1. The buffer must be page-aligned and be a multiple of the page size
2. The item must be `#[repr(C)]`
3. There must be no pointers or references of any kind

If these three things hold, then the object is safe to sling across the process boundary.

This crate adds the ability to annotate structs with `#[derive(flatipc::Ipc)]` to provide them with this functionality. When doing so, objects gain the `.into_ipc()` call that turns them into something that can be sent across process boundaries.

The resulting object has `.lend()`, `.lend_mut()`, `.try_lend()`, and `.try_lend_mut()` as functions.

candidates.title: Rkyv 0.8 - planning
candidates.body:
Adds a set of "out of workspace" tests to help plan a possible migration to rkyv 0.8.

This code isn't built as part of the Xous release, but incorporating it into the `main` branch allows us to reference it more easily in issues as we discuss the potential ramifications of this fairly significant change.

candidates.body:
Zip depends on time, which had some issues compiling on Rust v1.80: https://github.com/time-rs/time/issues/681

Update it to 2.1.6 in order to fix the issue.

Did not notice any apparent regression due to this update as of now.

candidates.title: WIP: Swap image loader
candidates.body:
This is the tracking branch for the next stage of swap implementation.

- [x] image creation support for IniS and detached swap blob
- [x] loader handling of IniS

Swap is written to a "detached blob" because the assumption is that we can't hold everything inside of a secure on-chip ROM. Thus, the image creator will kick out a "detached blob" for the swap blob, to be stored in an external device and loaded into swap on boot.

The loader has to handle this specially and setup swap accordingly.

candidates.title: Encrypted Swap, Phase 1
candidates.body:
This is the WIP for encrypted swap memory. This allows microcontrollers with a smaller amount of secure, on-chip RAM to run the kernel and core services, and use off-chip resources to store other services and applications.

This will take some weeks to fully implement, but the code is available here for inspection and comment as the implementation moves along.

The working spec for encrypted swap can be found at https://github.com/betrusted-io/xous-book/blob/main/src/ch10-00-swap-overview.md

candidates.title: WIP: BIO driver
candidates.body:
The ["better IO" (BIO)](https://github.com/buncram/cram-soc/tree/cram/deps/bio) block is a flexible I/O coprocessor inspired by the RPi PIO block, but coded using RISC primitives instead of the extremely CISC-y architecture of the PIO. 

In a nutshell, the BIO takes four RV32E+C cores with barrel shifters running out of a common 4kiB private memory space, and augments the cores with an "upper register bank" (r16-31) that allow each core to modify the GPIO pins with direct register writes, as well as perform inter-core and inter-host synchronization with FIFOs and events directly wired to the upper register bank. Furthermore, each core can synchronize to a clock-divider "quantum" by simply writing to a specific upper register, pausing execution until the quantum is up. The combination of these features allows all four cores to operate in lock-step, and to toggle I/O pins with cycle-accurate timing without having to count cycles.

While the PIO has a "simple" instruction set consisting of only a few instructions, the number of modifiers and single-cycle bit shifts implicit in the architecture creates very long critical paths that consume a large number of gates. Because each instruction does so much, the PIO can do an impressive amount with only 32 instruction words.

The BIO, on the other hand, is an embrace of the RISC philosophy. Using Claire Xenia Wolfe's PicoRV32 core in RV32-E mode, it has much less powerful instructions, but more of them: an instruction memory consisting of 4096 bytes (1024-2048 instructions, depending on how many compressed instructions you used). Note that most "programs" will use far less than that amount of RAM, and like the PIO they are intended to run out of registers only: in fact, 3 of the four cores can only perform loads (stores have no effect). However, due to the overhead of creating a RAM block, there's little advantage in modern semiconductor processes to go much smaller.

While not fully debugged, the BIO is synthesizeable. For FPGA targets, the BIO block is less than 25% as large as a spec-compliant PIO block (despite containing four RV32-E+C cores), and has no trouble with timing closure at 100MHz (the PIO can barely close timing at 50MHz). For ASIC targets, it's estimated that a BIO core should be able to run upwards of 800MHz, so even though the RV32E takes 3 cycles per instruction, it should be able to perform a 5-instruction shift-and-store SPI peripheral driver at 50MHz speeds, and could do a DMA bitbang at over 100MHz.

This PR tracks the Xous-side Rust drivers for the BIO (the RTL can be found [here](https://github.com/buncram/cram-soc/tree/cram/deps/bio). As of the creation of the PR, just the basic "hello world" functions have been tested, the PR will be bumped along over the coming months as I iron out all of the other bugs in the core.

candidates.title: bump release notes with latest PR
services/usb-device-xous: generic USB HID framework
candidates.body:
This PR adds the `HIDv2` USB mode for `usb-device-xous`, which allows applications to register themselves as USB HID handlers, hence sending and receiving USB HID reports.

Only one application is allowed to use `HIDv2` at a time -- the interface is extremely simple, to facilitate usage.

Users can specify any USB HID descriptor report they want, as long as it's less than 1024 bytes. 

Added an `hidv2` demo application that echoes back whatever the user sends over the wire.

candidates.title: WIP: Cramium cleanup
candidates.body:
This is a deep-dive refactor of the Cramium target interfaces to go from loosely held-together SoC validation code to something meant to be more durable and safe.

An interesting observation is that when designing a chip, the hardware interfaces can and will change. Often times at the last minute. Writing good Rust abstractions is like casting concrete -- it's a lot of effort, and only makes sense if the foundations have been laid out and won't shift. I do think the right process for using Rust in the context of an actively developed chip is to bodge things over initially with a lot of unsafe memory pokes, and digging into the hardware co-sim environment making sure that the hardware is even working. Usually all you're doing is something pretty simple -- like configuring a peripheral with a few pokes just to see it do some bus transactions, and you're eye-balling the results in a waveform viewer and doing some self-checks of correctness with peeks. You want the code layer at this point in time to be really loose, so you don't have unnecessary barriers holding you back from making the hardware correct.

However, once the chip goes to tape-out, nothing is going to change -- foundations are poured. At this point, it does feel more right to do a pass of clean-up to bring things up to standard. It does take some discipline, however, to grit through and toss out those peeks and pokes because the pile of abstractions necessary to do it right is not small.

Also, not every piece of hardware was made for Rust. While designing abstractions for the UDMA IP (which is from the Pulp project out of ETH Zurich & University of Bologna), it's pretty clear the designers did not have a strictly typed language like Rust in mind. It looks like a goal was to do some sort of "hardware polymorphism" where a common interface template is derived to enable DMA transfer to peripherals, and then you implement traits on a DMA channel that would be unique to each peripheral. It's nice conceptually...but there is a major wart, in that the peripherals all require access to some global shared state to manage clocks and events. So the constructor would ideally be able to reach into a global shared clock/event constructor, and Drop could do the same, to map and unmap the objects. I can't think of any way to implement this nicely in Rust, so, the constructor is simply marked as `unsafe` and you're meant to remember to map the clocks & events before creating an object, and you have no unmap after they Drop.

This is particularly tricky in the case that a peripheral is meant to be owned by different processes -- maybe if we had one process own all peripherals we could use a `static mut` of some sort and unsafe access to paper over this. But ideally the same abstraction works in raw-iron as it would in a multi-process system, and there is simply no way to do a `static mut` that's shared between different virtual memory spaces in Xous. Maybe the abstraction could be extended to use a "well known server" that manages global shared state and syscalls could be introduced into the constructor/destructor that manages clocks and what nots, and then use a `cfg` flag to generate separate code paths for raw-iron targets and OS targets. But I kind of don't like this approach because it hides the expense of these global operations -- philosophically I prefer the `unsafe` decorator and force the driver writer to think a little bit before introducing a potentially expensive global lock into some low-level code.

Anyways. These are mostly notes for myself, PR is WIP, but exists in a branch simply because `main` is protected.

candidates.title: Modify xtask to permit named BinaryFile
candidates.body:
A BinaryFile was previously identified only by its path, thus if a binary file represented an app rather than a service, there was no information that could go in the manifest for the gam. This let's one optionally specify a name for a BinaryFile. 

This may be too subtle, and we can decide on a different api, but I just added an Option<String> for the name in the CrateSpecs::BinaryFile and modified what needed to be modified to support that. Similar to the `name#url` syntax for a prebuilt app from the interwebs, I did a `name:path-to-binary` syntax to represent this, with the option of leaving that off as well. 

Note: I applied rustfmt to the files at the same time. I probably should not have done that so that it is easier to see just the changes. If you'd like me to redo this to fix that I can.

candidates.title: Add prehash signature check and prepare for env-variable hash passing
candidates.body:
This patch prepares us for environment variables to be introduced that allow us to extract the measured kernel hash from the loader.

As-is, the patch could be merged and the "only" thing that would break is signing the kernel, since the hash is not currently available (this is awaiting the environment variable implementation from @xobs). 

Here's the integration point for the environment variables:

https://github.com/betrusted-io/xous-core/blob/10154b8372c02486ae65d716722d4491624708be/services/root-keys/src/implementation.rs#L340-L345

candidates.title: Kernel memory fixes
candidates.body:
This fixes a few potential issues that were discovered in the kernel. One is major, and can result in reading uninitialized memory.

This does not yet solve the intermittent issues I've been seeing, but should probably be pulled in anyway.

candidates.title: Link sigchat to existing Signal account
candidates.body:
Linking sigchat to an existing Signal Account involves:

1. establishing a tls connection to the Signal Provisioning websocket server
2. obtaining a uuid via the websocket
3. displaying a qr-code on Precursor (containing the uuid and a pub_key)
4. scanning the qr-code with the primary Signal device
5. obtaining device registration via the websocket
6. completing the registration processing

steps 2, 3, 5 and 6 require libsignal

Refinements are made to `lib/tls` to facilitate presenting the tls trust modal to the user ONLY when none of the required CA's are trusted.

Note that the sigchat device-link process is temporarily hard coded to the **Staging** Service Environment (rather than the **Live** Service Environment). This means that during development/testing we will need to create a Primary Signal Account in the Staging Environment. This can be achieved with a spare SIM and [signal-cli](https://github.com/AsamK/signal-cli?tab=readme-ov-file#signal-cli).

Here's a WIP for refactoring how the layout() function works.

This passes a synthetic test, but for some reason when I run this with the rest of the program, I get a kernel panic on an invalid argument to a `memcpy` inside `<rkyv::std_impl::<impl rkyv::Deserialize<alloc::string::String,D> for <alloc::string::String as rkyv::Archive>::Archived>::deserialize>`. The panic is in thread 5 of mtxchat (but not quite sure which thread that is). 

Probably need to attach gdb to dig into this one a bit more, I'll try that tomorrow. Unclear how the layout engine changes would affect this...

candidates.title: RFQ: is it worth it to absorb the lates usbd-human-interface-device changes prior to forking?
candidates.body:
This PR fixes the `main` branch to track the latest changes in usb-human-interface-device (we were at API rev 0.2.1, this brings it up to 0.4.3).

Note that ... as far as I can tell most of the changes are cosmetic -- method names seem to be renamed to be more "rusty".

Aside from the renamings, the timer requirement is removed from keyboard devices.

@gsora - I'm fine to fork the crate at 0.2.1, but wanted to see what you thought about these changes. If you want me to pull these in prior to forking usbd-human-interface-device, I'm happy to. But I am also equally happy to fork at the older API rev if you see no clear advantage to adopting the changes.

Aside from that, I don't see any earth-changing fixes -- a bunch of dependencies got bumped, maybe they were bumped because security problems were found, or maybe they were bumped just because they could be bumped. The release notes are not clear on this.

candidates.title: Sigchat skeleton
candidates.body:
This is the skeleton of a Signal chat application - **sigchat**

The UI and local storage are provided by the xous chat library.

The structure of the Signal interface is modelled on [signal-cli](https://github.com/AsamK/signal-cli) by AsamK and contributors. `signal-cli` is a command-line interface for `libsignal-service-java`. It supports registering, verifying, sending and receiving messages. This development provides a welcome road-map of the various common transactions between a Signal client and server - see the `signal-cli` [Manual Page](https://github.com/AsamK/signal-cli/blob/master/man/signal-cli.1.adoc). This road-map is sketched out in `apps/sigchat/src/manager.rs`, but will be subject to refinement as sigchat development progresses.

The Rust implementation of each method stub in the `Manager` struct will ultimately make a call the official [libsignal](https://github.com/signalapp/libsignal#overview) library. 

> libsignal contains platform-agnostic APIs used by the official Signal clients and servers, exposed as a Java, Swift, or TypeScript library. The underlying implementations are written in Rust.

> This repository is used by the Signal client apps ([Android](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android), [iOS](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-iOS), and [Desktop](https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop)) as well as server-side. Use outside of Signal is unsupported.

libsignal is released under the AGPLv3 licence, so the plan is to wrap libsignal in a xous server (exposing a suitable API) under a compatible AGPLv3 licence - then to include this binary in a hardware image - making it available to sigchat.

candidates.title: implement an underlying graphics primitive for a busy bar animation
An App Loader
candidates.body:
This adds an app named `app-loader` which allows you to load apps at runtime onto your precursor device (instructions can be found in the README). I imagine that the main use-case for this would be to allow developers to quickly and easily test their apps on physical hardware. 
Currently, the method of transferring the binary files onto the device is done through a rudimentary http server, although this will probably need to be changed in the future since this seems to be the main bottleneck in loading apps (downloading the file over WiFi can take a few minutes but actually loading and executing the ELF file takes less than a second in my experience).
It is also worth noting that once an app is loaded onto the device, it cannot be removed since process destruction has not yet been implemented in Xous, and since you can't unregister tokens in `GAM` yet, it is thus impossible to load an app onto the device multiple times.
Outside of the `apps/` directory, I made the following changes:

- I modified `xous-api-log` slightly so that it can be built with no_std, which allowed me to use it in my modified `spawn` program
- I fixed a small bug in the kernel where, during the creation of a process, the pid was not set
- I modified `GAM` to allow the creation of new names at runtime and switching to different apps. As it would probably be a bad idea to allow any app to do this, only pre-registered apps may do these things.
- I added the aforementioned http server to send the apps to the precursor. I spent most of my time working on the lower-level app loading stuff, so it is very possible that this is implemented poorly.
- I modified `xtask` to allow apps with -'s in their names (because I wanted the app to be named `app-loader`), and I also added the ability to compile individual apps without compiling the entire image.

chosen_pr.title: Rkyv 0.8 - planning
chosen_pr.body:
Adds a set of "out of workspace" tests to help plan a possible migration to rkyv 0.8.

This code isn't built as part of the Xous release, but incorporating it into the `main` branch allows us to reference it more easily in issues as we discuss the potential ramifications of this fairly significant change.
